title: Add native module to get the list of all native modules for generating mocks
message:
Add native module to get the list of all native modules for generating mocks

In jest-expo we define mocks for Expo's native modules. We used to do this by enumerating over `ReactNative.NativeModules` but with the CxxBridge, `NativeModules` stopped being an enumerable object (it's now a magic proxy) so we need to get the list of native modules some other way. This commit introduces a small native module to get the list of other native modules.

It also adds a method to get more info about given modules, specifically their methods. We can then generate the appropriate mocks for each type of functions (e.g. mocks for "promise" functions should return a promise).

Test Plan: Call `NativeModules.ExpoNativeModuleIntrospection.getNativeModuleNames()` and see a list of all the native modules. Call `NativeModules.ExpoNativeModuleIntrospection.introspectNativeModuleAsync('ExponentCameraManager')` and get back info about the camera module's methods:

title: Make SecureStore work with Android < 23, new implementation
message:
Make SecureStore work with Android < 23, new implementation

Significant update to SecureStore on Android:
- Works on Android < 23, which can't store symmetric keys in the keystore
 - On older Android we use a technique called hybrid encryption, where we use AES to encrypt the data and RSA to encrypt the AES key. We store the asymmetric RSA key pair in the keystore (this is OK) and the encrypted AES symmetric key alongside the value's ciphertext.
- Uses its own shared preferences file (scoped to both experience and SecureStore), so if we want to list or remove all SecureStore entries for an experience, that's straightforward
- Stores encrypted entries in JSON objects so we can atomically add extra metadata about the encoding scheme we used to encrypt it
- For AES we use a different stream cipher (GCM), which doesn't require padding and is resistant to many-time pad attacks. The prior implementation used a block cipher.
- For RSA we still use PKCS#1 padding instead of OAEP because the keystore-compatible algorithm provider on older Android doesn't support OAEP.

Test plan:

- Android 23+: Load NCL (unversioned) on a device with Android 23+ and use the SecureStore example to test writing and reading back values.
- Android < 23: Load NCL (unversioned) on a device with Android 19 and use the SecureStore example. Verify with log statements that we're using the hybrid encryption path.
- Backwards compatibility for upgraded devices: Easiest way is to modify the code. Modify the `Build.VERSION.SDK_INT >= Build.VERSION_CODES.M` check in the write code path to always fail so we always use hybrid encryption. Load NCL (unversioned) on a device with Android 23+ and use the SecureStore example to write an item. Then restore the code and load NCL again on the same device and ensure we can read back the value. For good measure, write over the value again.
- Legacy SDK 20 support: Load NCL for SDK 20 and write a value. Load NCL (unversioned) and read back the value. Tested this on Android 6 -- I suspect this doesn't work on Android 4.4 or 5.x because it will try to use Spongy Castle and fail, but that doesn't matter because writing values failed in SDK 20 with Android 4.4 and 5.x.

title: Fix SecureStore issues (#945)

Fix SecureStore issues (#945)

#This PR addresses the following issues:
https://github.com/expo/universe/issues/889
https://github.com/expo/universe/issues/884
https://github.com/expo/universe/issues/878

- The constants for `Expo.SecureStore.KeychainAccessible` enum weren't properly exported in the SDK.
- Docs updated to more accurately reflect the `Expo.FileSystem.KeychainAccessible` enum.
- When `Expo.SecureStore.getValueWithKeyAsync()` doesn't find a value, `<null>` should be returned instead of throwing
- Android error messaging ambiguity addressed
- Android encryption method changed from `RSA` to `AES` to allow for long string storage.
- Long string stress case added to test suite.

## Backwards compatible:
The changes to SecureStore are now backwards compatible, existing users who upgrade won't experience any data disruption.  Attempts to encrypt using a legacy `KeyStore.Entry` will generate a new entry and encrypt with AES.  Attempts to decrypt a legacy value that's never been re-encrypted with AES will be decrypted with legacy methods.

RCTBridge now defines `jsContextRef` (not publicly though) and RCTBatchedBridge and RCTCxxBridge implement it, so we can just get the JSContextRef from the bridge directly now.

We also check if the executor is of the right type by testing if `bridge.executorClass` is set. This is the same way that RCTCxxBridge checks if it is using the JSC executor (`executorClass` won't be set) or not. - Serves a new AASA file from our website (both exp.host and expo.io). Before we served a signed file but as of iOS 9+ we can serve an unsigned file as long as we use HTTPS. Since we support iOS 9+ only anyway, the plaintext version is a lot simpler to think about.

This is hard to test in advance because a real device actually has to go out to expo.io and fetch the AASA file so just going to test in prod with this plan:

1. put up a webpage on another domain that links to https://expo.io/@ide/bubblebounce
2. open it in safari and tap the link
3. verify that Expo opens (and hopefully opens the experience)
4. do the same with https://expo.io/ and ensure that Expo does not open -- we want only experiences to open for now (later profiles too)

Summary:
- I did not test the shell app builder, shell app expert people please do and let me know how it goes or if I missed something.
- We should probably use a shared debug keystore (tell me if this is stupid and I don't know what I'm talking about) so we can just have one maps api key that we can use in development, and we need to generate an api key with the sha1 fingerprint for our release keystore (@jesse plis).
- We need a way for users to get the sha1 fingerprint for keystore for their shell app so that they're able to register their own API key. (@skevy plis).  - iOS was pretty straightforward, no api keys necessary, but @ben you will need to add support for the prefixes SM (https://github.com/lelandrichardson/react-native-maps/blob/master/ios/AirMaps/Callout/SMCalloutView.m) and AIR (https://github.com/lelandrichardson/react-native-maps/blob/master/ios/AirMaps/AIRMap.m) to the iOS versioning script.
- I don't know how we handle versioning of dependencies like Google Play Services Maps, which is required by this lib.

Test Plan:
- Create an Android API key: https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/android-api/signup
  - You will need your sha1 keystore fingerprint, something like this: `keytool -list -v -keystore ~/.android/debug.keystore -alias androiddebugkey -storepass android -keypass android`
  - Put the API key into exponent/__internal__/keys.json, GOOGLE_MAPS_API_KEY
- Build in debug mode and try adding a map somewhere:
```
  import MapView from 'react-native-maps';
  // or Exponent.Components.MapView

  <MapView
    initialRegion={{
      latitude: 37.78825,
      longitude: -122.4324,
      latitudeDelta: 0.0922,
      longitudeDelta: 0.0421,
    }}
  />
```
- Test it out in shell app builder
